message:
Hi All,
I had mentioned group peer reviews in the first class, but that feels like a long time ago :)  I wanted to repeat so that there were no surprises.  With your first group, you are doing 2 designs and 1 implementation.  After the 3 projects, you will each submit a private self/peer assessment:  it will address what you did in the design projects and implementation, how you rate yourself; you will also write what your team mates did and you will assess them.  

Looking forward to your designs tomorrow.

data.message: Yes, at least 2
Yes.  I would be grateful if you can share with me how much time you take to complete one review.
About 5 minutes. Enough time to skim the critique and focus on a good point and an area that can be improved.
we can still go back and review old critiques, right?
Yes.

message: So we should be doing reviews for all assignments as a part of the participation grade, correct?

DESIGN #2
-----
Submissions should be made by 10am Thursday, September 25.

Design Project #2:    Design a visualization using data from group communication (i.e.  Facebook groups, Twitter, Mailing lists, online gaming community, etc.). Within your presentation, include a storyboard showing the dynamics of your visualization from beginning to end  (i.e.  how one logs in, how transitions occur, etc.)

Please follow the following structure:

- describe the motivation for creating this visualization
- describe the intended audience for this visualization
- describe the main questions/problems you plan to answer/understand with this visualization
- describe the tools, analysis you will need to help answer your questions
- in the storyboard, show the visualization flow from beginning to end.

This portion of the project is as much about communication as it is about the design and idea.  The designs will be graded using the following rubric:

1.  did you present the above 5 sections in your proposal  (5/100)  
2.  is the problem you are addressing clear  (15/100)  
3.  is the approach you are using to address this problem clear (15/100)  
4.  does your design answer your question (20/100) 
6.  does the storyboard present a clear and cogent presentation of your story - does it have a coherent organization and flow (20/100) 
6.  is your approach and/or design novel (15/100)
7.  did you incorporate material presented in class or from the readings (10/100)

I would encourage all of you to include visuals sooner in your presentations.  I also recommend not putting whole paragraphs on the slides.  If you want to include more information for peer studio evaluation, feel free to add comments in the notes area of the slides.  Also, please include more explicitly how the class material influenced your design or data set.

Please include a link to your design (ppt, pdf, or your choice of media) in your peer studio submission.  Only 1 member of each team needs to submit - please include the names of *all* the members in your presentation.
For class, please bring computer dongles so you can  present from your own machine.  Most students in the past have preferred this.
(Note:  No implementation is required for the design.  A good design now will help you as you work on implementations later in class.)

data.message:
Hi Aditi,  Thanks for asking.  Yes, the design project is similar to what you did for the last design.  The topic is different.  Here, you are exploring some element of a group.  Whether it is comparing different groups or a member to a group.  Be prepared to present in class.  

PLEASE start these now!  It takes time to explore data  to come up with a feasible and engaging design.

Once you have presented both design projects, you will be asked to implement *one* of them.  Note, the implementations need not be complete.  but you need to show a good faith effort and show in class what you created.  Please stop by office if you want help prioritizing what to implement.
Nice question!  By the way, is there going to be feedback provided for the last design assignment that we could use to improve this upcoming one?
Yes, there will be feedback by this weekend.
We have to explore an existing visualization correct?
Hi Jarai, I don't understand.  The assignment is to create a visualization using "group" social data.

caption: embed-ssl.ted.com
message:
"Lying is an attempt to bridge that gap, to connect our wishes and our fantasies about who we wish we were, how we wish we could be, with what we're really like."

This is another Ted talk about lying. Pamela Meyer, a liespotting expert, shares her insights on motivation behind lying, patterns of deception, and patterns of truth. She says lying is a cooperative act and that we can exempt from collaborating in a lie.

We are not building a lie detector for this class, but I think there is still a merit in considering lying, which is a common practice in our social life, in relation to our behavior in an SNS environment.

Hi All, 
Julia asked an excellent questions about the design assignment:  She asked whether the data needs to be accurate/real.  

To hopefully clarify:  You are not required to implement anything for this part of the assignment.  However, the more 'real' the data, the better you will understand the problem.  I always encourage students to explore their data deeply in the design process so that they have accurate assumptions.  For this assignment simply describe the interactive aspects, but use realistic-like data.  (You may not know all the patterns of your data until you later do a thorough analysis, but do explore the data you plan to use and include real examples from it.)

Hi All,  the assignment and rubric for Design #1 is below:

Submissions should be made by 10am Thursday, September 11.

Design Project #1:    Design a visualization using data from personal communication (i.e.  email, SMS, FB inbox messages, personal communication within a large group etc.). Within your presentation, include a storyboard showing the dynamics of your visualization from beginning to end  (i.e.  how one logs in, how transitions occur, etc.)

Please follow the following structure:

- describe the motivation for creating this visualization
- describe the intended audience for this visualization
- describe the main questions you plan to answer/understand with this visualization
- describe the tools, analysis will you need to help answer your questions
- in the storyboard, show the visualization flow from beginning to end.

This portion of the project is as much about communication as it is about the design and idea.  The designs will be graded using the following rubric:

1.  did you present the above 5 sections in your proposal  (5/100)  
2.  is the problem you are addressing clear  (15/100)  
3.  is the approach you are using to address this problem clear (15/100)  
4.  does your design answer your question (20/100) 
6.  does the storyboard present a clear and cogent presentation of your story - does it have a coherent organization and flow (20/100) 
6.  is your approach and/or design novel (15/100)
7.  did you incorporate material presented in class or from the readings (10/100)

Please include a link to your design (ppt, pdf, or your choice of media) in your peer studio submission.  Only 1 member of each team needs to submit - please include the names of *all* the members in your presentation.
For class, please bring computer dongles so you can  present from your own machine.  Most students in the past have preferred this.
(Note:  No implementation is required for the design.  A good design now will help you as you work on implementations later in class.)

message:
Critique #4  (due September 9, 10am central time)
---------------

Please read the 2 papers linked off the website for September 9. These are:

A review of overview+detail, zooming, and focus+context interfaces by Cockburn, Karlson, and Bederson
Choosing Colors for Data Visualization by Stone
 
For each of the 2 papers, please write a critique (approximately 280 words for each paper).

In the critique include:

1) a two sentence summary (limit the summary to 2 sentences - the crit should not be a summary of the paper)

2) what you feel are the positives of the work, i.e. what is exceptional

3) what you think could use improvement

4) how you might continue the work or what you might pursue next

These critiques will be graded on a 3 point scale. Most students will receive a 2 (if the above 4 criteria are met). A grade of 3 will be given sparingly if a critique is exceptional.

The readings help catalyze class discussion and should be completed on time. A point will be deducted for each day a critique is late.

caption: www.lynda.com
message:
There is a lynda.com tutorial about D3.js for anyone that's interested. We all U of I students have a free subscription to lynda.com videos. 

http://www.lynda.com/sdk/D3js-tutorials/Data-Visualization-D3js/162449-2.html

data.message:
selectAll would select all the p tags within the DOM (even if they don't actually exist within the DOM, you can use 'append' to actually create them) 
data would bind those numbers as data to those respective p tags 
the style basically refers to the styling of the tags, and in this case it refers to the font size. The parameter is the data which has has been bound to the p tags so it will return 4px, 8px, 15px, 16px, and so on and so forth. 

Also, documentation is your friend. A little hard to read at first, but it will make your life much easier :)     https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki/API-Reference
Also go through eloquent Javascript to understand closures and what not. http://eloquentjavascript.net/

Ohhh I was following the tutorials on the GitHub page but didn't see the documentation hahaha... Thank you! 

But how might this be used? It returns 4px, 8px, etc. but where does the input come from that would determine that output?
Or wait, is it just setting the font size of each p to those numbers in order?

I'm assuming you're talking about the parameter for style when you say input, I would recommend that you go through on how data is being bound here and see if it helps. Read the documentation on selection.data and go through some examples
A few hours later and I think I have the basics down...

message:
I'm going through the D3 tutorial and I'm not really sure what the following code does (excuse the awkward Facebook spacing):

d3.selectAll("p")
    .data([4, 8, 15, 16, 23, 42])
    .style("font-size", function(d) { return d + "px"; });

I have submitted the draft on peerstudio but the draft that I wrote in Word is not organized in the form of questions (like peerstudio). Should I mail it to TAs as well?
Please type it in to the system directly.  We thought it would accept a link, but it does not.
Naren, no need to email as well if you wrote in the fields of PeerStudio.
I would like to discuss our experiences using this in class tomorrow  to see if we will continue.

message: Just for clarification: are our summaries supposed to be ~280 words each like the lecture slide yesterday said, or ~700 words each? I have been hearing different numbers from different people.

data.message: I'm unable to submit create/edit a draft on peerstudio. I was redirected to their waitlist page instead. Anyone facing the same problem?
Hi Joshua, you are not alone.  The creators have been notified. Will let you know as soon as we hear back.
Will we also use Piazza for discussion?
We will be using this group and the mailing list (when created) for discussion.
Can we use Piazza instead?

We tried that in the past.  With 3 forums, students were repeating the same questions in the three different channels instead of focusing on one.    Of the three (Facebook, piazza, mailing list, Facebook overwhelmingly generated the most productive discussion.  And people responded faster.  Piazza posts were quite rare.
Since most of courses use Piazza for discussion, I think it would be better to centralize courses related questions in Piazza.

None of the available tools have great interfaces yet.  I have not yet found Piazza to be much more useful than FB.  The overhead of logging into FB, looking at the mailing list, Peer Studio, possibly Compass for grades, and Piazza adds layers of communication complexity.  We can take a vote in class tomorrow - if there is an overwhelming demand for Piazza, then I'll consider it.  Otherwise, it would be simpler to focus on FB and email.
Thank you, professor
The submission issue is now fixed.  Please let me know if you have difficulties submitting!
Professor, for the account, should we sign up using illinois email? Or we can just use Coursera account? Thanks.
Whichever you prefer.
